list_elements.text: Reflect on how you use your time
Identify effective time management strategies
Apply time management techniques
Consider time management in relation to employability

components.subtitle: Reflection: how do you currently use your time vs. how you want to use it
components.text: Think about these things.  Do you…

list_elements.text: feel in control of your time?
keep track of everything you need to do?
realise where your time goes?
know how to manage distractions?
use time management strategies effectively?
have time for yourself?

components.subtitle: Complete the form below with your thoughts.

list_elements.text: It’s not only about how much time you spend studying, but using that time

You’re more likely to achieve well if you spend enough time studying and use that time
well
You feel more confident and in control when your time is organised
Using time well means you have more choice what to do with the time saved
It prepares you for the workplace

components.text:
Look in your module handbook and see how much time it is recommended
you spend studying.

You may need more than this if your study background isn't
straightforward, or English isn't your first language.

sections.subtitle: Find out where the time goes

components.text:
Have you ever thought you didn't know where your time went? Many of us have!

Try keeping a log for a week and see exactly how you spend your time. It might be very different from what you think.

See the activity log here: Mindtools website

Do you really need to spend your time in this way? What things could you change to make more room for studying?

However, remember to make time for hobbies, socialising and keeping healthy.

Decide what is important and urgent, and leave tasks which aren't important or urgent until later.

Do you really need to do the things that aren't important?

sections.subtitle: Make a plan, and stick to it

components.text:
Plan exactly when you are going to do what you need to do.

Work backwards from deadlines: what you need to do and how long it will take (e.g. early brainstorming, research methods, searching for information, organising & selecting information, drafts, checking, hand-in).

Put your plan somewhere you can see it or will look at it regularly.

If your plan isn't working - change it! Don't try to stick to something that doesn't work for you.

What distracts you?

How can you stop this?

Try this app: Forest App

list_elements.text: Match tasks to the time you have available
Use blocks of time, e.g. 30 mins

Mix things up: try time blocks of different lengths, and change tasks frequently if
you get bored easily

Plan efficient breaks: longer breaks, micro-breaks, find out what works for you, but
don't work for hours on end without a break
Set early deadlines before hand-in date to allow for last minute alterations
Keep a track of time by using a timer, for example
Make use of available support, e.g. library
Organise your stuff: manage your files and your space, label things clearly
Beware of distractions online: monitor how long you spend
Set times for browsing online as it can easily take up too much time

Allow time for others to respond to you - don't expect tutors or fellow students to
respond straight away - they may be busy too!

components.text:
What strategies do you have for saving time?

Think or share your ideas.

Some things you could try...

list_elements.text: Note-writing: write directly onto laptop if you prefer, using key words
Copying files: keep them somewhere they can be accessed from anywhere
Make the most of spare moments, e.g., listening to a podcast while travelling

Looking for notes: label them clearly with large headings so you can find them
easily

Reading: use techniques for faster reading (see Reading Strategies presentation),
and select and read only what is relevant

Writing references: keep a full record so you don’t have to look them up again (or
use an electronic system)

Thinking: capture ideas as you have them, e.g. in a notebook or make a recording
on your phone

Organising: don’t note same information twice, use highlighting to group
information, keep information in the same place

Avoid duplicating effort: where permitted (e.g. collaborative tasks), share the tasks
so you’re not doing the same things
